entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 24, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Boston Red Sox @ Toronto Blue Jays, 4:07p

Summary

Top of the watchability board and it earns it: gNERD 15.73 pits Cy-caliber Garrett Crochet against the name-brand gravity of Max Scherzer, with Boston desperate for wins while Toronto tunes up minus key pieces. If you‚Äôre saving one window, this is the one.

Crochet‚Äôs elite pNERD (12.28) backs up a season of power and precision‚Äîhe‚Äôs piled up 240-plus strikeouts across nearly 200 innings with a sub-3 FIP, and he‚Äôs been on a heater (13‚Äì1 over his last 19 starts). Scherzer, meanwhile, is trying to steady things after an abbreviated, injury-tinged year that recently included a 0.2-inning, 7-run blowup; the name still pops, but the underlying run prevention hasn‚Äôt. The team inputs say ‚Äúwatch‚Äù: Boston‚Äôs high tNERD rides a sharp bullpen and plus fielding and baserunning, while Toronto‚Äôs tNERD blends elite defense with a contact-first offense‚Äîbut the Jays are without Bo Bichette to finish the regular season, and they just lost Ty France while activating Anthony Santander. Stakes add juice: Toronto has already clinched and is jockeying for seeding, while Boston‚Äôs margin is thin enough that every Crochet day feels like a must-have.

(A model from OpenAI generated the above text using instructions, the NERD scores, and these sources: 1, 2, 3, 4.)

New York Mets @ Chicago Cubs, 5:05p

Summary

This one sits atop the watchability heap: a gNERD 15.72 that‚Äôs above the 95th percentile historically, plus real stakes after the Mets staged a wild comeback against a Cubs team trying to halt a skid. Rookie Jonah Tong‚Äôs mystery-box arsenal meets Matthew Boyd‚Äôs Wrigley-tuned precision‚Äîyouthful whiffs versus veteran sequencing.

The appeal here is two excellent tNERDs colliding: the Mets bring top-tier thunder (barrels and NL-leading power vibes) against a Chicago club that runs the bases well and catches everything, and the contrast on the mound sweetens it. Boyd has been All-Star-caliber run prevention with a FIP around 3.10 and a notably strong home track record; if he‚Äôs in the zone early, Chicago‚Äôs bullpen finally gets a breather. Tong, making just his fifth MLB start, offers novelty and upside‚Äîa ride-y four-seamer paired with a revamped Vulcan-change that‚Äôs spiking whiffs‚Äîand he‚Äôs fresh off a five-inning, eight‚Äëstrikeout scoreless start. Add in New York‚Äôs late-inning punch (Nimmo, Alvarez, Alonso) and the Cubs‚Äô urgency to stop the slide, and you‚Äôve got action in all phases even if the pNERD side is merely average. If you like stakes, swing decisions, and outfield walls tested, this is your pick.

(A model from OpenAI generated the above text using instructions, the NERD scores, and these sources: 1, 2.)

Miami Marlins @ Philadelphia Phillies, 3:45p

Summary

Jes√∫s Luzardo facing his former club is the hook; Kyle Schwarber‚Äôs homer chase is the fuse. With a gNERD of 15.41‚Äînear the top of today‚Äôs slate and above the 95th percentile historically‚Äîthis grades as must-watch. Luzardo‚Äôs pNERD (10.01) is carrying real teeth: an xFIP- of 81 with mid‚Äë90s velocity, whiffs to spare, and recent outings with double‚Äëdigit strikeouts, now doing it in Phillies pinstripes after the winter trade from Miami. Ryan Weathers isn‚Äôt window dressing; the lefty brings 96.9 mph heat, works quickly, and sits near league‚Äëaverage run prevention by xFIP, enough to make this a real duel if his strike rate cooperates. Philadelphia‚Äôs higher tNERD (8.35) is powered by bats and baserunning, and Schwarber just launched No. 54 as the Phillies press for the NL‚Äôs top seed‚Äîthough Trea Turner remains sidelined while Alec Bohm recently returned. Miami arrives on a seven‚Äëgame heater after an 11‚Äëinning comeback at this park, and both bullpens grade volatile, so late‚Äëinning entropy is firmly in play; even J.T. Realmuto‚Äôs hand scare came back clean.

Pittsburgh Pirates @ Cincinnati Reds, 3:40p

Summary

Two triple‚Äëdigit fastballs, one home‚Äërun pinball machine, and a playoff race on a tightrope: if you pick one pitchers‚Äô duel, make it this one.
Skenes vs. Greene is peak gNERD‚Äînear the top of today‚Äôs slate and above the 95th percentile historically‚Äîbecause the arms dramatically outshine the bats.

Paul Skenes brings elite underlying run prevention (mid‚Äë2s FIP) with upper‚Äë90s heat and that splinker/changeup mix that turned heads, while Hunter Greene counters with a league‚Äëbest fastball and newly tidy strike throwing; he just spun a one‚Äëhit, nine‚Äëinning shutout and owns top‚Äëtier xERA/K‚ÄëBB traits. Meanwhile, Cincinnati‚Äôs urgency is real after dropping ground in the wild‚Äëcard chase, and Pittsburgh‚Äôs offense has lived near the cellar, which is why the gNERD leans so hard on the starters despite Great American‚Äôs homer boost. In short: high‚Äëoctane stuff, real stakes, and a bandbox where even tiny mistakes matter‚Äîwatch for whiffs, not rallies.

Milwaukee Brewers @ San Diego Padres, 1:10p

Summary

gNERD 15.15 says ‚Äúwatch this,‚Äù and the context agrees: Dylan Cease‚Äôs whiff machine meets Milwaukee‚Äôs high-tNERD chaos in a game with real seeding juice. San Diego has already clinched and is pressing for better positioning after a walk-off to open the set and a 7‚Äì0 follow-up, and Xander Bogaerts just returned to the lineup. Cease carries the day‚Äôs premium pNERD (8.49), built on power and misses (97 mph, big whiff rates) and supported by 200+ strikeouts this year, the profile that best stress-tests Milwaukee‚Äôs contact-first approach. Chad Patrick‚Äôs pNERD (4.85) is more modest, but his mix-y, cutter/changeup look and league-average xFIP (xFIP- 98) can still turn innings tidy if he gets ahead. Team-wise, this rates high because both clubs bring entertainment drivers: Milwaukee‚Äôs top-tier tNERD (9.60) leans on speed, defense and depth, while San Diego‚Äôs bullpen grades extremely well and the Petco broadcast is a plus. The Brewers are patching a rotation thinned by Brandon Woodruff‚Äôs lat strain and Jos√© Quintana‚Äôs calf IL stint, which elevates the Padres‚Äô strikeout edge but also spotlights Milwaukee‚Äôs elite pen. Relative to today‚Äôs slate and even the historic distribution, this sits near the top for pure watchability.

Minnesota Twins @ Texas Rangers, 5:05p

Summary

Come for deGrom‚Äôs curtain call; stay to see whether a 24-year-old with upper-90s can hang. At gNERD 13.10‚Äîcomfortably above the day‚Äôs average‚Äîthis is a premium pitching watch.

Jacob deGrom (pNERD 9.38, xFIP- 81, 97.5 mph) is lined up for his final scheduled start, and with Corey Seager and Marcus Semien shut down, the mound is the Rangers‚Äô show. Probables: deGrom vs. Taj Bradley. DeGrom has dominated at home (2.39 ERA) and his run prevention remains strong (3.58 FIP), aligning with the model. Bradley brings velocity (96.3) and youth (pNERD 6.16), but a league-average xFIP- (105) and shaky strike rates make him volatile‚Äîin a fun way. Minnesota‚Äôs tNERD leans on a good bullpen, handy if Bradley exits early; Texas adds watchability with plus defense and baserunning. DeGrom is coming off a clunker (5 ER vs. Houston), which is context, not destiny. With a strong pNERD average (7.77) and a gNERD that sits above the historic 75th percentile, expect elite pitch quality, tight run prevention, and enough uncertainty to keep you from channel surfing.

Detroit Tigers @ Cleveland Guardians, 3:40p

Summary

Two teams knotted atop the Central with the tiebreaker in Cleveland‚Äôs pocket makes this a high‚Äëstress watch; add Flaherty‚ÄìBibee round two and you‚Äôve got playoff vibes without the bracket. The opener of this set swung the standings into a dead heat and gave Cleveland the head‚Äëto‚Äëhead edge, so every pitch here tilts the division math. With a gNERD of 12.75, this lands above today‚Äôs average and in the historical upper quartile, and the reasons show up on the field: Detroit brings barrels and speed, Cleveland counters with elite defense, plus baserunning and a late‚Äëinning bullpen edge‚Äîprime ingredients for a taut finish. Jack Flaherty owns the stronger pNERD and an xFIP- of 89, works a brisk pace, and just held Cleveland to one run over five; Tanner Bibee‚Äôs underlying is more average, but he‚Äôs recently limited Detroit to one run over six and has strung together three sharp September starts. The probables are indeed Flaherty vs. Bibee, and after Cleveland‚Äôs earlier win tightened the race, this sequel is appointment viewing for those who enjoy defense-and-bullpen chess against a lineup that can still punish mistakes.

Los Angeles Dodgers @ Arizona Diamondbacks, 6:40p

Summary

A strikeout artist on a heater meets a desperate lineup and two mercurial bullpens; this one rates high on pure stuff and playoff stakes.
If you like lefty whiffs with a chance of late-inning chaos, you‚Äôve found your window.

With a 12.72 gNERD, this sits above today‚Äôs slate average and the historic 75th percentile. Snell‚Äôs second-half indicators (3.08 FIP, 2.74 xFIP) back the surge, and MLB‚Äôs own research just dropped the nugget that he became the first since 1905 to stack consecutive starts of 11+ K, ‚â§2 hits, ‚â§2 walks, 0 runs, 0 XBH. Nelson isn‚Äôt a pushover: post-break he‚Äôs tightened the strike-zone math (3.47 FIP, 3.75 xFIP; September xFIP 2.83), giving Arizona a viable counter. The stakes add juice ‚Äî the Dodgers‚Äô lead shrank to 1.5 games while Arizona sits a game out of a wild card ‚Äî and they just played a bullpen-rock fight that flipped late. That matters because Arizona‚Äôs relief group has been a season-long soft spot by advanced metrics, even as roles churned. entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 23, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Score Time (PT) Visitors Score Home Score Starter (V) Score Starter (H) Score

If you‚Äôre prioritizing, tune for Webb‚Äôs command and the infield action; stay late only if the Cardinals‚Äô bullpen door creaks open.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 22, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Score Time (PT) Visitors Score Home Score Starter (V) Score Starter (H) Score

Brewers already clinched the NL Central while the Padres‚Äô magic number is skinny, so leverage should arrive early and stick around all night.

At 13.82, this game sits first among today‚Äôs matchups and flirts with the historical upper tier, driven by elite tNERDs: Milwaukee‚Äôs speed/defense/relief combo (tNERD 9.71) against a Padres crew buoyed by a high‚Äëend bullpen (tNERD 7.45). Robert Suarez just hit 40 saves, and Petco‚Äôs run‚Äëprevention vibe only tilts things further toward drama by the ‚Äòpens. Freddy Peralta‚Äôs pNERD is merely above average, but his whiffs (10 K last time out) play, even if his 2025 peripherals (FIP/xFIP) lag his shiny run prevention‚Äîsomething FanGraphs tied partly to Milwaukee‚Äôs defense, which fits today‚Äôs tNERD profile. On the other side, Nick Pivetta brings improved K/BB rates and a history of homer risk that Petco tends to soften; he‚Äôs coming off a mortal turn vs. the Mets.

Roster notes nudge the watchability needle: William Contreras has been listed as probable after a hand scare, while Xander Bogaerts remains out with a foot fracture. gNERD says prioritize this; your eyes will likely agree.

This gNERD 9.58 is built on the arms‚ÄîpNERD 8.84 (Sale) and 6.84 (Gore) are well above today‚Äôs average‚Äîwhile both teams‚Äô tNERDs sit near the basement, so expect the pitchers to do the entertaining.

Sale‚Äôs underlying skill still screams appointment viewing: a 71 xFIP- here and a sub-3 xFIP projection elsewhere (2.92), plus he became the fastest ever to 2,500 career strikeouts earlier this season. Gore isn‚Äôt far behind on the intrigue scale, pairing 95+ velocity with a roughly league-better xFIP- (90) and 182 punchouts in 157.2 innings. The recent head-to-head offers a tidy preview: Sale dominated; Gore matched zeros into the sixth; Atlanta finally broke Washington late.

If you require a storyline beyond the K‚Äôs, Atlanta arrives riding an eight-game run of 5+ runs scored, though today‚Äôs low team-NERDs caution against expecting a shootout; this is watchable because the lefties are.

St. Louis Cardinals @ San Francisco Giants, 6:45p

Summary

The gNERD puts this near the bottom of today‚Äôs slate, but it‚Äôs a stealth watch if you like contrasts: a 42-year-old tinkerer on a late-season upswing vs. a 24-year-old contact manager backed by a slick defense. Add the Giants‚Äô thin wild-card pulse and you‚Äôve got just enough stakes to keep the remote holstered.
Justin Verlander has finally found bite: seven scoreless in his last outing and only three runs allowed over his past five starts, part of a two-month course correction after an 0-8 opening stretch. The matchup also carries a callback‚Äîearlier this month St. Louis erased six scoreless from Verlander with a ninth-inning ambush, the same night he passed Gaylord Perry on the all-time strikeout list.
Michael McGreevy arrives off seven zeros against Cincinnati; he‚Äôs more sequencing than sizzle, with an xFIP profile around average and the Cards‚Äô gloves and bullpen built to make that play.
Offensively, both clubs are light on barrels, and St. Louis is further dulled without Willson Contreras, whose season-ending shoulder strain leaves a lineup gap.
If this stays tight late‚Äîand the Giants‚Äô staff has been volatile of late‚Äîthere‚Äôs upset potential.

Detail

New York Yankees @ Baltimore Orioles, 10:35a

Summary

Top gNERD on the slate (13.52) rides a two-ace vibe: Kyle Bradish‚Äôs post‚ÄìTommy John whiffs meet Cam Schlittler‚Äôs 98-mph rookie voltage. Layer in a Yankees lineup that barrels like a cooperage and an Orioles club searching for stability, and this tilts toward must-watch.

Bradish‚Äôs pNERD (7.95) is backed by real-world nastiness: 10 strikeouts in his return with mid‚Äë97s heat, and he‚Äôs stacked 15 Ks over his past 12 innings without allowing a homer, the kind of swing-and-miss profile that fits his xFIP‚Äëdriven component here. Schlittler‚Äôs pNERD (7.92) comes from youth and gas; he‚Äôs shown bat-missing chops (13 whiffs on 95 pitches vs. DET) but the command can wobble (five walks, didn‚Äôt finish five in his last start), which adds either chaos or charm depending on your disposition. The rookie‚Äôs road split helps‚Äîopponents are hitting .192 away from the Bronx‚Äîand New York has won five of his last six starts. On the team side, the Yankees‚Äô strong tNERD (8.14) is powered by elite barrels, while Baltimore‚Äôs lower tNERD (3.04) reflects shaky defense/bullpen even as Bradish offers a bright spot for a roster that‚Äôs cycled through a record-tying 70 players.

Summary

High-stakes AL West theater with a premium arm on the marquee: Logan Gilbert (elite pNERD 10.72) lines up against depth starter Jason Alexander, as Seattle defends a slim lead and Houston fights to stay in the bracket. Cal Raleigh just reset the Mariners‚Äô single-season homer record, and Yordan √Ålvarez is sidelined with a significant ankle sprain, so the vibes (and thump) tilt Seattle.

With a gNERD of 12.82 (upper tier among today‚Äôs games), the watchability here is driven by the contrast on the mound: Gilbert‚Äôs run-prevention indicators are sparkling (xFIP- 66 in our model) and he typically works deliberately, while Alexander brings a lower whiff profile but a quicker tempo. The matchup is official as probable: Gilbert vs. Alexander. Seattle‚Äôs offense brings real punch (strong batting runs and barrels in the tNERD mix), and Raleigh‚Äôs power binge only sharpens that edge; meanwhile, Houston‚Äôs best features are glove and bullpen, which could keep this close if they reach the middle innings on script. For added intrigue, Jose Altuve has handled Gilbert reasonably well in his career, a pocket of resistance the Astros will need. And after Seattle‚Äôs series-securing win, the standings pressure is very real, heightening every plate appearance.

Toronto Blue Jays @ Kansas City Royals, 11:10a

Rookie vs. metronome makes for sneaky-watchable baseball: Toronto hands the ball to Trey Yesavage, fresh off a franchise-debut record 9 strikeouts, to stop a skid, while Michael Wacha tests whether savvy can outfox swing-and-miss. The gNERD sits near the historical median, but the plot points are timely enough to keep a thumb off the remote.

Yesavage‚Äôs second look comes after five punchout-filled innings that doubled as a club debut record, the kind of pNERD mystery box (0.00) that can spike a game‚Äôs fun factor on contact. Toronto needs it, having produced just three runs across four games with one total at-bat with RISP in this set, and now juggling the rotation after Chris Bassitt hit the IL. Wacha‚Äôs pNERD is modest (3.40) with an xFIP- of 109, and he‚Äôs coming off a concussion-return clunker (7 R, 2 2/3 IP), though he previously cruised eight innings of one-run ball vs. these Jays. Kansas City still has a pulse, with Bobby Witt Jr. and Vinnie Pasquantino powering recent wins and Pasquantino riding a heater. With Toronto‚Äôs better tNERD (7.17 to 4.46) and a rookie with whiffs to spare, this is a mid-tier gNERD (10.01) game lifted by meaningful stakes and the allure of discovery.

Padres‚ÄìWhite Sox is a ‚Äúbring your bullpen‚Äù watch: San Diego‚Äôs playoff push meets Chicago‚Äôs rebuild, with Michael King and Sean Burke more supporting actors than headliners. It‚Äôs mid-tier by gNERD (8.11), pulled down by a low pNERD duo, but Padres urgency and a soft White Sox lineup keep it watchable.

King‚Äôs pNERD (3.85) reflects average run prevention (xFIP- 97) and modest bat-missing, and he‚Äôs still ramping after a September IL return; he even ate some lumps at Citi Field last week. Burke‚Äôs pNERD (2.30) tracks with a shaky run estimators profile (xFIP- 117) and traffic (1.47 WHIP), the kind of mix that can force early bullpen cameos. If that happens, advantage Padres: their relief corps just locked down the previous game while Adrian Morejon nabbed the win.

Macro-wise, San Diego‚Äôs tNERD (7.30) tops Chicago‚Äôs (2.77) and the standings explain why: Padres are 84-71 and chasing October; the Sox are 58-97 and short-handed (Luis Robert Jr. out), while Xander Bogaerts is also sidelined. Against a Chicago offense that ranks near the bottom by AVG/SLG, even King‚Äôs contact-leaning approach can play. Net: below today‚Äôs average gNERD, but the playoff stakes, a bullpen edge, and a favorable matchup nudge it onto the screen.

Los Angeles Angels @ Colorado Rockies, 12:10p

Summary

This is the lowest gNERD on the board today, but it still comes with two decent hooks: Mike Trout just joined the 400-homer club, and Kyle Freeland‚Äôs added sweeper has given him a modest whiff bump. If you‚Äôre hunting for chaos, Coors plus two thin bullpens is a reasonable bet even when the watchability math shrugs.

The model dings this matchup because both tNERDs are underwater (Rockies deeply so), with Colorado‚Äôs bats, defense, baserunning, and bullpen all grading poorly; that last item is watchable in its own way when late innings get rubbery. The Angels at least barrel the ball (excellent barrel-rate component), while their fielding and relief work drag. On the mound, rookie Caden Dana is an unknown in NERD terms (pNERD 0), but he‚Äôs a 21-year-old top prospect who‚Äôs bounced between Triple-A and the bigs this year‚Äînovelty points if you like scouting in real time.

Freeland‚Äôs overall run prevention hasn‚Äôt wowed, but the sweeper has been a real addition, and his 2025 FIP sits closer to ‚Äúserviceable‚Äù than the surface stats suggest. If Trout‚Äôs milestone hangover includes another loud swing and Dana finds early strikes, this clears its low bar; otherwise you‚Äôre watching to see which bullpen blinks first.

  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Boston Red Sox @ Tampa Bay Rays, 4:05p

Summary

Today‚Äôs gNERD headliner (14.25) offers contrasting thrills: Boston‚Äôs quick-strike, bullpen-backed outfit vs. Tampa Bay‚Äôs run-happy chaos. With Kyle Harrison‚Äôs youthful heat and pace against Adrian Houser‚Äôs contact-management act, there‚Äôs motion baked into nearly every inning.

Harrison‚Äôs pNERD 8.35 tracks with the ingredients you want to watch‚Äîmid‚Äë90s velocity and a brisk 16.1s tempo that keeps the camera cutting; Houser‚Äôs 4.16 and league‚Äëaverage underlying run prevention (xFIP around 3.9) hint at more balls in play than whiffs. Boston‚Äôs tNERD 8.93 is powered by an elite bullpen (+1.62) and real defensive value (+1.11), the sort of leverage-and-run-prevention cocktail that tightens late frames. Tampa Bay‚Äôs tNERD 7.06 is TV‚Äëfriendly in a different way: top‚Äëtier baserunning (+1.92) paired with shaky gloves (‚Äë1.24) and a solid pen (+0.74) means traffic, gambles and mistakes‚Äîi.e., entertainment. Storyline spice: Boston just took the opener and has beaten Tampa Bay seven straight, while the Rays hand the ball to Houser after an uneven acclimation.

Among today‚Äôs slate (1.63‚Äì14.25), this sits on the summit; historically, it‚Äôs near the 95th‚Äëpercentile tier‚Äîworthy of your first screen.

Summary

A must-see rookie vs. a post-surgery power arm, with a win-now Mets lineup looming ‚Äî this one has juice. At gNERD 14.02, it sits near the top of today‚Äôs slate and around the historic 95th percentile, so the watchability signal is loud.

Nolan McLean‚Äôs 9.64 pNERD is backed by real indicators: a tidy xFIP- (73) and brisk pace (16.8s), plus a month-old debut that‚Äôs become a 1.19 ERA run with record-setting company for a Mets rookie. Cade Cavalli (5.76 pNERD) brings 97 mph and the intrigue of a 2025 return from March 2023 Tommy John ‚Äî the stuff is there, the consistency less so. The matchup itself appears set: McLean vs. Cavalli for the first time. Team-wise, the Mets‚Äô hefty 11.59 tNERD rides thunder (barrels, batting runs) and a capable pen, while Washington‚Äôs 1.05 tNERD is dragged by defense and relief ‚Äî and the Nats‚Äô error-strewn opener didn‚Äôt help. Add stakes: New York‚Äôs in a tight wild-card race, which elevates every pitch.

Shane Bieber‚Äôs high-end pNERD (9.51) vs. a rookie revelation makes this a prime watch, especially with Toronto seeking order after Kansas City‚Äôs 27-hit, 20‚Äì1 deluge.
Noah Cameron works fast and throws strikes, and he draws a glove-forward Jays club that turns balls in play into outs.

At gNERD 13.45, this sits near the top of today‚Äôs slate and in the historical upper tier. Bieber‚Äôs profile is appointment viewing: a 65 xFIP- with a brisk pace, plus a solid track record against this opponent; he‚Äôs also the right antidote after Toronto‚Äôs bullpen absorbed the blowout while KC‚Äôs starter went 7‚Öî. Cameron‚Äôs rookie year has been legitimately good, and while his underlying run prevention is closer to average (xFIP- ~99), the tempo and age-driven upside keep the pNERD afloat. Toronto‚Äôs tNERD edge comes from real defense and capable bats, but they‚Äôre doing it without Bo Bichette; meanwhile, KC just lost plus-defender Kyle Isbel to the IL. Net: tune in for Bieber‚Äôs whiffs, pace from both sides, and the subplot of whether the Jays‚Äô run prevention tidies up last night‚Äôs mess.

Sugano‚Äôs rookie baseline is shakier (4.89 FIP), though he‚Äôs been tweaking after potential pitch‚Äëtipping chatter and has recently tightened the screws, which adds some genuine novelty value. He‚Äôs also the Orioles‚Äô first 10‚Äëwin rookie starter since John Means in 2019, so the ‚Äúwhat exactly is he?‚Äù factor is alive. Layer in Jazz Chisholm Jr.‚Äôs 30‚Äì30 arrival and the Yankees‚Äô power profile, and this grades as Yankee‚Äëleaning, mostly for Rod√≥n and the bats rather than the pitching matchup‚Äôs pure NERD.

At a gNERD of 8.31, this sits a bit below today‚Äôs slate average, but Detroit‚Äôs strong tNERD (7.10) nudges watchability up thanks to better barrels and actual on-base action, plus plus baserunning, even if their pen can wobble. Los Angeles Angels @ Colorado Rockies, 5:10p

Summary

This is the basement of watchability: the slate‚Äôs lowest gNERD collides with a Rockies team trying to sidestep the record books for all the wrong reasons. Still, Coors chaos plus two contact-heavy starters might accidentally make this weirdly entertaining.

gNERD 1.63 sits well below both today‚Äôs average and the historical median, with tNERDs that scream ‚Äúproceed at your own risk‚Äù (Angels 1.40; Rockies -0.89). The arms don‚Äôt rescue it: pNERDs of 1.86 (Hendricks) and 0.89 (M√°rquez) track with below-average underlying skill, led by xFIP- marks of 117 and 126 and minimal whiff rates. Hendricks‚Äô 86 mph profile and tiny SwStr% invite balls in play; M√°rquez is just back from a biceps issue and hasn‚Äôt missed many bats since returning. If you like contact and baserunning bedlam, Coors‚Äô elevated BABIP environment (.332 since 2015) reliably inflates both.

If you need a storyline, Colorado just avoided matching the 2024 White Sox and still needs wins to dodge the 1962 Mets‚Äô loss mark, while the Angels arrive on an eight-game slide. The Angels at least bring barrels (10.6%), but dreadful fielding and spotty bullpens on both sides point toward high-variance mess rather than crisp pitching. Hendricks did spin seven scoreless his last time out, but this venue punishes optimism.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 19, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Score Time (PT) Visitors Score Home Score Starter (V) Score Starter (H) Score

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Boston Red Sox @ Tampa Bay Rays, 4:35p

Summary

Top gNERD on the slate, and it earns it: ace-level Garrett Crochet (pNERD 12.26, xFIP- 62) squares off with a restored Drew Rasmussen at the Rays‚Äô temporary outdoor digs, where Boston‚Äôs elite bullpen meets Tampa Bay‚Äôs track team. If you like whiffs plus stolen-base chaos with late-inning leverage, this one checks every box. By our model this game‚Äôs gNERD is 17.32, the day‚Äôs highest and well above the historical 95th percentile, and the matchup brings real storylines with it: Crochet, now locked up long-term in Boston, has paired upper-90s heat with strike- and swing-miss rates that scream ace; Rasmussen, back from his internal-brace comeback and under a two-year deal, has been efficient more than flashy. With Sox tNERD strength coming from defense and a top-shelf bullpen, the Rays‚Äô counter is speed; they‚Äôve been swiping bags in bunches and just rode Chandler Simpson (and steady Yandy D√≠az) in a shutout of Toronto. The venue twist matters, too: Tampa Bay is hosting at George M. Steinbrenner Field this season, adding some outdoor variability to a club built on run prevention and legs.

(A model from OpenAI generated the above text using instructions, the NERD scores, and these sources: 1, 2, 3.)

Milwaukee Brewers @ St. Louis Cardinals, 5:15p

Summary

Triple-digits versus guile: Jacob Misiorowski, the rookie who no-hit St. Louis for five innings in his debut, squares off again with Sonny Gray, who just punched out eight Brewers last week.
Milwaukee‚Äôs sprint toward the division flag meets a shorthanded Cardinals lineup, with Willson Contreras done for the year.

At a gNERD of 15.80, this lands above the 95th percentile of historical games and near the top of today‚Äôs slate, and the ingredients check out: a high-octane pNERD duel (Misiorowski 10.21; Gray 6.97) plus a large tNERD edge for Milwaukee (9.72 to 4.69). Misiorowski‚Äôs appeal is obvious‚Äîhe averages 99-plus with top-of-era perceived velocity (fastball 101.3 mph; a slider that looks like mid-90s), which plays beautifully against a St. Louis offense that‚Äôs been thinning and underperforming. Gray isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúveteran savvy‚Äù; his underlying run estimators have outpaced the surface, and he just held Milwaukee to two runs over five in their latest meeting, giving this real counterpunch potential. Add Milwaukee‚Äôs elite baserunning and deep bullpen (both strong tNERD components) against a Cards club trying to manufacture runs, and the watchability case is strong: power stuff, contrasting styles, and stakes. If you like velocity art, Misiorowski alone is worth the click.

Seattle Mariners @ Houston Astros, 5:10p

Summary

High gNERD and real stakes: two power righties with strong pNERDs square off to break an AL West tie. Bryan Woo arrives off a career-best 13-K start, while Hunter Brown has been dealing in September, making this a pitching-forward watch.

At 13.62, this game grades in the top decile of historic gNERD and well above today‚Äôs average, driven by both arms‚Äô xFIP- (Woo 80, Brown 76) and upper-90s velocity that should keep whiffs and called strikes flowing even if pace isn‚Äôt brisk. The watchability hook is simple: elite run prevention deciding a division race that‚Äôs currently level, with Houston missing Yordan Alvarez (ankle), thinning the lineup against Woo‚Äôs splitter/sinker mix.

Brown‚Äôs recent form (6.2 IP, 2 ER vs. ATL; 1.42 September ERA) supports the pNERD, and Houston‚Äôs defense/bullpen combo has carried weight all year, so every baserunner matters. Seattle brings punch (13 HR in its last 10) and enough bullpen to shorten the game if Woo hands off cleanly.

Translation: a top-tier gNERD duel with playoff leverage, premium stuff on both sides, and contrasting support systems‚ÄîAstros‚Äô gloves and pen vs. Seattle‚Äôs power‚Äîtilting each pitch into event television.

(A model from OpenAI generated the above text using instructions, the NERD scores, and these sources: 1, 2, 3, 4.)

Atlanta arrives with five straight wins, but just lost high-leverage lefty Aaron Bummer to the 60-day IL, a nudge toward late-inning entropy. Elder teased a rebound (2.72 FIP over four starts) before Houston stung him, so expect contact and sequencing to matter more than punchouts. Net: gNERD 9.23 sits under today‚Äôs mean (10.73), but Detroit‚Äôs high tNERD and real playoff pressure justify a spot on your flip-card.

If you‚Äôre hunting a pristine pitchers‚Äô duel, look elsewhere; if you‚Äôre into a Hall of Famer managing guile while Michael Lorenzen steadies a short-handed staff, this has a certain pull.

The gNERD sits at 8.99, a shade below today‚Äôs average, because the pNERD half is modest: Scherzer‚Äôs underlying effectiveness has been middling (xFIP- 110) while Lorenzen is nearer league average (101). Toronto‚Äôs bats, though, just faceplanted in a 4‚Äë0 dud, so style points likely come from run prevention more than fireworks. Kansas City‚Äôs depth just took another hit with Kyle Isbel and Ryan Bergert landing on the IL, which won‚Äôt help an offense already dragging in our inputs. With a gNERD of 6.69‚Äîwell below both today‚Äôs average and the historical median‚Äîthis leans fringe‚Äëwatch unless Cease shoves; his pNERD 7.66 is backed by plus velocity and an xFIP- of 86, the clear driver of watchability. Cease also enters off six efficient innings (1 R, 6 K) and, yes, this is his first start against his former club since the trade, adding a tidy narrative edge.

Team vibes don‚Äôt help: Padres tNERD is 0.00 and the White Sox sit at 2.91, but San Diego has flashed a little recent thump (13 HR in 10 games). Xander Bogaerts‚Äô foot issue potentially trims the Padres‚Äô contact cushion. If you‚Äôre watching, it‚Äôs for two things: Mike Trout hunting No. 400 in the thin air and a rookie lefty taking his first real Coors Field test. Otherwise, this profiles as today‚Äôs lowest gNERD game, with bottom-tier bats and uncertain pitching.

The model is down on it for good reason: both clubs sit near the floor in team NERD, and the average pitcher NERD is 2.30. Angels rookie Mitch Farris is at least new; he debuted well (5 IP, 1 R) before Seattle tattooed him for five in four, so intrigue beats polish. Bradley Blalock‚Äôs results have been rough ‚Äî a season line around an ERA in the high eights/nines and five runs in three innings last time out ‚Äî and Colorado‚Äôs staff has yielded the most homers in MLB, which at Coors is‚Ä¶ ambitious. Trout sits on 399 career homers, and this ballpark remains the league‚Äôs friendliest for scoring, so the milestone watch is real. With the Angels‚Äô bullpen wobbling lately (6.17 ERA over the last 10), volatility ‚Äî not virtuosity ‚Äî is the entertainment path. If you like messy, altitude-aided baseball and 2026 auditions, there‚Äôs a certain charm; otherwise, you can skip guilt-free.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 18, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

12.6 10:35a Athletics 7.3 Boston Red Sox 8.7 J.T. Ginn 5.7 Brayan Bello 3.4
11.9 10:10a San Diego Padres 7.5 New York Mets 11.8 Randy V√°squez -0.5 Jonah Tong No data

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Cleveland Guardians @ Detroit Tigers, 10:10a

Summary

Tarik Skubal is appointment viewing, and the gNERD agrees: this is today‚Äôs headliner. An ace chasing hardware meets a gloves-and-bullpen outfit that can turn a 2‚Äì1 game into television, not background noise.

At 15.74, the gNERD sits atop today‚Äôs slate and above the 95th percentile of historical games, and the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù starts on the mound: Skubal‚Äôs pNERD (13.48) towers over Tanner Bibee‚Äôs (4.12), backed by elite whiffs, strikes, velocity, and an xFIP- in the 60s. MLB‚Äôs latest poll has him as the AL Cy Young favorite, with league-best run-prevention indicators like FIP and a mountain of strikeouts. Detroit‚Äôs bats add watchability via barrels and above-average offense, while Cleveland‚Äôs profile leans the other way: light pop but plus defense and a bullpen that rates far better than Detroit‚Äôs, a recipe for late-inning leverage. The standings raise the stakes, too: Detroit leads the AL Central while Cleveland lurks a few games back and in the Wild Card chase. If Skubal shoves as expected and Bibee keeps enough traffic off base to hand it to that Cleveland pen, you get crisp pace, ace-level stuff, and meaningful innings‚Äîexactly what a top-tier gNERD promises.

Chicago Cubs @ Cincinnati Reds, 4:15p

Summary

Hunter Greene‚Äôs triple-digit fastball and bat-missing slider against a freshly clinched Cubs lineup is the attraction; a 15.12 gNERD rides his ace-level pNERD and Chicago‚Äôs high-tNERD offense to near-top-tier watchability. Chicago just locked a postseason spot, but Greene‚Äôs stuff is the sharper variable. Greene has lived 99‚Äì100 mph with elite miss; in 2025 his four-seamer and wipeout slider have produced hefty whiff rates and run-value gains that back the model‚Äôs love for him, not just the radar gun. Opposite him, the Cubs are lined up to start Colin Rea, a contact-leaning righty; the underlying reads (mid‚Äë4s FIP/xFIP, sub‚Äë20% K%) suggest fewer fireworks from the visiting mound, which only sharpens the Greene-versus-bats contrast. The team split matches the numbers: Chicago‚Äôs top-end tNERD reflects barrels, fielding, and on-the-bases action that keep innings lively, while Cincinnati‚Äôs lower tNERD tempers the chaos. With this game near the top of today‚Äôs slate and above the 95th percentile historically, the watch is Greene trying to blow past a lineup that punishes mistakes‚Äîand whether the Cubs‚Äô depth, likely rotating pieces after clinching, can crack him before the bullpen arrives.

San Francisco Giants @ Los Angeles Dodgers, 7:10p

Summary

Aces, groundballs, and a lineup with a sledgehammer‚Äîthis lands near the top of the watchability board. Yoshinobu Yamamoto was one out from a no-hitter on Sept. 6 and then shoved seven-plus innings with 10 K against these Giants days ago; Logan Webb gets another crack after L.A. tagged him for six.

With both pNERDs around 9‚Äîdriven by elite xFIP- marks (Webb 68, Yamamoto 73)‚Äîyou‚Äôre tuning in for sequencing, sinkers, and weak contact as much as whiffs. The gNERD of 14.54 sits near the top of today‚Äôs slate (and around the 95th percentile historically), but the tilt in team watchability matters: the Dodgers‚Äô bat-first tNERD is buoyed by real thump, including Shohei Ohtani reaching 51 homers, while the Giants‚Äô bats and baserunning trail.

There‚Äôs recent spice, too: Patrick Bailey‚Äôs walk-off slam beat Yamamoto last week, the Dodgers just steadied a wobbly bullpen after some high-profile late-game chaos, and San Francisco still has wild-card oxygen‚Äîenough stakes to keep every pitch tense.

If you prefer contrasts, it‚Äôs groundball artisans versus a top-barrel offense; if you prefer plot twists, it‚Äôs a late-inning stress test. Either way, this grades as appointment viewing.

With the AL East‚Äìleading Blue Jays visiting the speed-and-bullpen Rays at their temporary Tampa digs, expect a tight, style-contrast watch.

A gNERD of 13.01 sits well above today‚Äôs average, and the ingredients check out: Toronto‚Äôs high tNERD is built on real run creation and slick defense, while Tampa Bay counters with elite baserunning and a sturdy relief corps, the recipe for late-inning friction. Bassitt hasn‚Äôt missed many bats this year but continues to limit damage (one earned over five in his last turn), the quintessential ‚Äúhow did they only score one?‚Äù outing. Baz brings near-a-K-an-inning and, while volatile of late, still flashes the frontline traits that once made him a headliner.

Add context: the Jays arrive atop the division while the Rays, sub-.500, are auditioning future pieces; and the setting itself‚ÄîSteinbrenner Field, the Rays‚Äô 2025 stand-in‚Äîadds novelty. Toronto‚Äôs doing this without Bo Bichette, yet the lineup‚Äôs top-tier OBP keeps traffic moving; Tampa Bay‚Äôs Fairbanks-led pen can still slam a door. If you like contrasting paths to run prevention and a plausible bullpen coin flip, this deserves your screen.

Jacob deGrom is the reason to tune in; an Astros lineup missing Yordan √Ålvarez and leaning on Cristian Javier is the reason this feels more like an ace showcase than a duel. Houston just banked two tight wins in the series and is jostling near the top of the AL West race, but this matchup tilts toward ‚Äúcan they survive deGrom?‚Äù

On the numbers, a mid-pack gNERD 10.62 sits just below today‚Äôs average, lifted by deGrom‚Äôs hefty pNERD 9.63 and dragged by Javier‚Äôs 0.19. deGrom‚Äôs skill signals still sizzle (xFIP- 79, 97.5 mph) and he worked seven efficient innings his last time out; Javier brings a rough xFIP- 120 and one of the slower paces on the slate. Houston is listing Javier for this one after using an opener/bullpen mix earlier in the set, so expect fewer whiffs and more balls in play on his side. Texas adds watchability with plus defense and aggressive baserunning, while Houston‚Äôs pen has shouldered a lot of late innings‚ÄîBryan Abreu is closing with Josh Hader still shelved by a shoulder issue. In short: not the slate‚Äôs crown jewel, but if you like elite stuff versus a battered contender trying to cobble 27 outs, this scratches the itch.

Come for Ryan Weathers, stay for Coors-induced entropy. gNERD 8.58 trails today‚Äôs average, but a healthy, hard-throwing Weathers versus a raw McCade Brown at altitude raises the entertainment ceiling.

Weathers just returned from the IL and spun five scoreless frames in his first start back, with the pNERD inputs here‚Äîplus-dial velocity and a solid xFIP-‚Äîsuggesting real bat-missing potential against a lineup that‚Äôs been scuffling. Meanwhile Brown is in the tryout phase; his early big-league line features a bloated WHIP and sub-2.0 K/BB, though his most recent outing was his cleanest to date. Expect variability, which at Coors usually means runs.

Team-wise, the tNERD gap tracks with reality: Miami‚Äôs youth-and-bargain build is at least watchable, while Colorado‚Äôs defense and bullpen have been rough, and the club just dropped its 110th game despite a late rally. That combo keeps the floor low but the chaos high. If you want a narrative hook, it‚Äôs Weathers auditioning for 2026 innings while trying to dodge the Coors multiplier, plus Hunter Goodman‚Äôs power giving the Rockies a puncher‚Äôs chance. Not elite by today‚Äôs slate, but volatile enough to earn your second screen.

Summary

Today‚Äôs gNERD bottoms out at 5.75, but there‚Äôs just enough novelty and potential chaos to justify a strategic channel-flip. Tyler Wells‚Äô third start back from elbow surgery squares off with Mart√≠n P√©rez‚Äôs contact-first craft while Baltimore‚Äôs kids keep auditioning and Chicago tries to stop the bleeding.

Relative to today‚Äôs slate, this is a low-watchability matchup: weak average tNERD and pNERD point to modest stuff and lineups that don‚Äôt consistently punish mistakes. Still, Wells has been crisp in a tiny sample, allowing a .146 opponents‚Äô average and a 0.60 WHIP across 11.2 innings, and the Orioles have won his first two starts back; that ‚Äúcomeback curiosity‚Äù is the main pNERD hook. Chicago, meanwhile, is riding a five-game skid and hands the ball to P√©rez, a pitch-to-contact lefty (7.2 K/9) who‚Äôs been steady if unspectacular. If you‚Äôre here, you‚Äôre likely watching Wells‚Äô feel returning and Baltimore‚Äôs prospects taking big-league reps; if not, expect some slop‚ÄîChicago‚Äôs defense and baserunning haven‚Äôt helped‚Äîand possibly late-inning wobble after the O‚Äôs bullpen leaked last game.

Texas Rangers @ Houston Astros, 5:10p

Summary

Playoff stakes meet steady vs. mystery: Texas rolls out Merrill Kelly while Houston counters with rookie AJ Blubaugh‚Äîand the Astros might be patching the lineup if Yordan √Ålvarez‚Äôs sprained left ankle keeps him out. The gNERD 10.94 plants this around the middle of today‚Äôs slate, but the variance dial is high if the rookie holds up and Houston must win without its primary left-handed thump.

For watchability, Kelly brings skills over sizzle: a better-than-average xFIP- (91), lots of strikes, and few free passes (~2.5 BB/9), the kind of profile that travels in a hitter‚Äôs park; since Texas acquired him at the deadline, he‚Äôs kept them in games and just helped cap a sweep last week. Blubaugh is the wild card‚Äîlimited major-league track record, bounced between Sugar Land and Houston, and now asked to navigate a contact-heavy lineup; the novelty factor is real, the data less so.

NERD tilts the subplots: Houston rates well for run prevention thanks to a sturdy bullpen and defense, while Texas brings plus baserunning and gloves. With the division and wild-card margins razor-thin after Houston‚Äôs series-opening win‚Äîand √Ålvarez headed for imaging‚Äîevery pitch has leverage, and Blubaugh‚Äôs first trip through a deep order could decide whether this plays like a crisp Kelly showcase or a bullpen relay.

If you like whiffs and a track meet, lean Brewers; if you like volatility, Dana‚Äôs mystery box versus a contender is your hook.

The gNERD (10.56) sits a tick above the historic median and roughly middle of today‚Äôs slate, and the reason is mostly Milwaukee‚Äôs big tNERD (9.53): they run and defend, and even with a bruised pitching staff they‚Äôve stayed elite. Peralta brings real swing‚Äëand‚Äëmiss (176 K, ~10 K/9) with a run‚Äëprevention profile supported by a mid‚Äë3s FIP, while the Brewers have already banked a postseason berth despite injuries to Jos√© Quintana and closer Trevor Megill.

L.A.‚Äôs tNERD (1.75) drags: the offense hits .228 but does supply damage (near‚Äë200 homers), and the defense and bullpen have leaked runs, an entertaining recipe if you enjoy chaos. They‚Äôre also shorthanded, with Logan O‚ÄôHoppe on the 7‚Äëday concussion IL and Jorge Soler shifted to the 60‚Äëday.

Net: watch for Peralta carving while Milwaukee‚Äôs legs pressure a shaky Angels unit, with the side plot of Dana auditioning for 2026. That combination makes this solidly watchable even without ace‚Äëvs‚Äëace sizzle.

Cincinnati Reds @ St. Louis Cardinals, 4:45p

Summary

Playoff stakes meet contact ball: Cincinnati‚Äôs push collides with St. Louis‚Äôs glove-first identity in a park that turns big flies into warnings. With a gNERD of 8.08 (below today‚Äôs average), expect craftsmanship more than spectacle‚Äîand just enough tension to keep you off the remote.

Andrew Abbott‚Äôs mid-pack pNERD (4.85) is built on strike-throwing and pace rather than whiffs (xFIP- 105, quick 17.8s tempo), which pairs with a Reds lineup light on barrels but good on the bases. Michael McGreevy‚Äôs profile is youth-and-control over strikeouts (40 K, 69 IP; excellent walk rate), and Busch Stadium suppresses homers, so contact should rule. The Cardinals have graded out as one of the better defensive units this season, a nice complement to their pitch-to-contact tendencies, though losing Masyn Winn for the year dings the infield wizardry. Nolan Arenado is back in the lineup, while Willson Contreras left the opener with biceps tightness, and Cincinnati sits two games off the final NL wild-card spot‚Äîlive implications without the guarantee of fireworks. Add it up and the watchability leans on defense, bullpen competence, and late-inning leverage more than raw stuff or slug.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 15, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Philadelphia Phillies @ Los Angeles Dodgers, 7:10p

Summary

Top of today‚Äôs watchability board: a gNERD 15.29 with star power and two pitchers whose xFIP- (both 87) says ‚Äúquality‚Äù before the anthem. Playoff stakes sweeten it‚ÄîLA‚Äôs chasing a bye while Philly‚Äôs already in, so this series can tilt seeding.
Ranger Su√°rez arrives in full groove‚Äîone run over his last 24 innings‚Äîand works briskly, while Emmet Sheehan brings mid‚Äë90s ride, a whiff‚Äëheavy profile, and the best pNERD on the slate; his comeback from Tommy John and recent seven‚Äëinning gems add narrative fuel.
Lineup theater is unavoidable: Shohei Ohtani sits one swing from another 50‚Äëhomer season, with Mookie Betts scorching of late, opposite a Phillies group that‚Äôs been launching 19 homers over its last 10 games.
The components love the watch: Philadelphia‚Äôs high tNERD rides real skills‚Äîplus baserunning, solid fielding, and a broadcaster boost‚Äîwhile the Dodgers counter with big barrels and a top bullpen.
Given that today‚Äôs gNERD range tops out here, add in Sheehan‚Äôs velo/whiffs and Su√°rez‚Äôs efficiency, and you‚Äôre looking at the rare game that grades out analytically and narratively‚Äîmust‚Äëclick before the bracket locks.

Chicago Cubs @ Pittsburgh Pirates, 3:40p

Summary

A live‚Äëwire rookie with real bat-missing stuff meets a savvy strike‚Äëthrower fresh off the IL, wrapped around one of baseball‚Äôs most athletic lineups. At a 13.08 gNERD‚Äîcomfortably above the historical 75th percentile‚Äîthis belongs in the day‚Äôs upper tier of watchability. Ashcraft is the headliner: upper‚Äë90s fastball and breaking balls that have played to a sub‚Äë3.00 FIP with just two homers allowed in roughly 58 innings, most of them short, efficient stints; the intrigue is how deep he‚Äôs allowed to go. The matchup tilts toward action because the Cubs pair top‚Äëquartile barrels with elite baserunning and plus defense, a profile that stresses young power arms as much on contact management and hold times as on pure velocity. Taillon‚Äôs pNERD is middling, but he works quickly, lands strikes, and he just returned from a groin IL stint; earlier this summer he handled Pittsburgh with 7 K in 6.1 IP. Pittsburgh‚Äôs bats have been light on impact (last in MLB in homers), which nudges the watch toward Chicago‚Äôs side. Also: the Cubs arrive off a 4‚Äì3 win keyed by a late Nico Hoerner double.

Toronto Blue Jays @ Tampa Bay Rays, 4:35p

Summary

A top-prospect debut meets a bullpen mystery and a 44-homer thunderstick: that‚Äôs plenty of reason to peek in early. With a gNERD of 12.56‚Äîtop-quartile by the historic distribution and comfortably above today‚Äôs average‚Äîthis one earns your remote.

Toronto‚Äôs tNERD is buoyed by real run creation and elite gloves (fielding runs +1.70), and the stakes are tangible after a sweep that kept them atop the AL East. Trey Yesavage, 22, brings strikeout volume (160 K in 98 MiLB IP, ~14.7 K/9) and a north‚Äìsouth mix headlined by a riding fastball and splitter, and he‚Äôs confirmed to start. Tampa Bay hasn‚Äôt named a starter, which often signals an opener/bulk day‚Äîfitting a club whose bullpen grades as a relative strength in the model‚Äîeven as their team defense lags. The Rays‚Äô draw is Junior Caminero, in the midst of a breakout and closing on the franchise single-season homer mark. With 0.00 pNERDs on both sides, watchability skews toward novelty (Yesavage‚Äôs first look), contrasts (Jays‚Äô defense vs. Rays‚Äô power/baserunning), and pennant-race context rather than tidy projections.

New York Yankees @ Minnesota Twins, 4:40p

Summary

Yankees barrels vs. Twins bullpen is the hook here, with Aaron Judge stalking a fourth 50‚Äëhomer season and Simeon Woods Richardson making his first career start against New York. There‚Äôs juice in the stakes, too: the Yankees sit narrowly atop the AL wild-card field, so every Rod√≥n start matters.

At a gNERD of 9.76, this is a shade below today‚Äôs average, but it plays up because the components pull in opposite directions. The Yankees‚Äô strong tNERD (8.07) is powered by premium contact‚Äîan elite barrel rate‚Äîso New York‚Äôs lineup drives the watchability. On the mound, Carlos Rod√≥n‚Äôs middling pNERD (4.67) masks a useful underlying: his xFIP- is better than average and he‚Äôs diversified the arsenal in 2025, adding a sinker and leaning more on the changeup per Statcast, which can neuter righty power when located. Woods Richardson‚Äôs low pNERD (1.99) reflects a shaky xFIP-, and the data backs it: his changeup has been hammered while a nascent splitter flashes out-pitch traits‚Äîboom‚Äëbust viewing against a patient, power-heavy offense.

Minnesota‚Äôs tNERD lags, but a legitimately strong bullpen shortens games and adds late‚Äëinning intrigue if they‚Äôre close. Add Judge‚Äôs 50‚Äëhomer watch and recent long-ball form, and you‚Äôve got a solid, if not top‚Äëshelf, pick.

Texas Rangers @ Houston Astros, 5:10p

Summary

Playoff leverage meets pace-contrast: Texas brings Jack Leiter‚Äôs 97 mph heat while Houston counters with quick-working Jason Alexander, and the AL West race makes every pitch feel louder. If Jos√© Altuve‚Äôs sore foot keeps him limited, Houston may again lean on run prevention and Yainer D√≠az‚Äôs timely thump.

At 9.57, the gNERD sits a hair below today‚Äôs average, mostly because the pNERDs are modest, but both clubs grade above today‚Äôs team-average watchability. Leiter‚Äôs xFIP- (111) says ‚Äúvolatile stuff,‚Äù yet the velo and youth boost pNERD, and he‚Äôs handled Houston capably in two prior meetings (12.1 IP, 10 K). Alexander‚Äôs profile is steadier (xFIP- 101) and he works fast, which tends to keep things crisp.

Context makes this pop: the Astros opened a pivotal homestand with Brown/Valdez saved for Seattle, Alexander set to start, and standings that squeeze both sides. Houston‚Äôs offense has been uneven, but D√≠az recently decided a game and Alexander spun seven scoreless. Meanwhile, Texas arrives shorthanded‚ÄîCorey Seager (appendectomy) and Marcus Semien (foot) are tracking returns but not quite there‚Äîwhich has dragged their recent bat quality.

Add in Rangers‚Äô strong defense/baserunning versus Houston‚Äôs elite bullpen and positive ‚Äúluck‚Äù signal, and you‚Äôve got a divisional grinder with clean run prevention and just enough swing-changer potential to merit attention.

San Francisco Giants @ Arizona Diamondbacks, 6:40p

Summary

A solid ‚Äúlate-night channel surf‚Äù pick: Zac Gallen‚Äôs steadier underlying line (4.41 FIP/4.08 xFIP) meets a volatile rookie in Kai‚ÄëWei Teng, with wild‚Äëcard positioning still very much in play. Arizona‚Äôs bats and legs add juice, but their bullpen‚Äôs wobbles mean even a lead won‚Äôt feel safe.

The gNERD sits at 8.34‚Äîjust below today‚Äôs average‚Äîbecause both pNERDs hover around average, yet the ingredients are interesting: Arizona‚Äôs tNERD is buoyed by positive batting and baserunning components, while San Francisco‚Äôs offense brings fewer barrels and rough baserunning but a sturdier bullpen that can flip late innings. On the mound, Gallen‚Äôs results have improved since the deadline (4‚Äì2, 2.83 ERA) even as the peripherals say ‚Äúgood, not dominant,‚Äù and he just saw these Giants last week. Teng brings strikeouts but also traffic; he‚Äôs flashed swing‚Äëand‚Äëmiss (11.1 K/9; eight Ks at Coors) alongside walks and short outings‚Äîwatchable chaos in a bottle.

Storylines help: Ketel Marte fouled a ball off his foot midweek but scans were clean and he returned over the weekend, keeping Arizona‚Äôs top‚Äëorder thump intact. If you‚Äôre ranking options, tune for Gallen‚Äôs pace and command early, then stick around to see whether the Giants‚Äô bullpen can outlast Arizona‚Äôs in the late frames.

Baltimore Orioles @ Chicago White Sox, 4:40p

Summary

Watch this for Kyle Bradish; debate the rest with your conscience. If he resembles the guy who spun seven no‚Äëhit innings on this mound last year, that‚Äôs your hook.

At a gNERD of 7.93, this lands below today‚Äôs average (9.94) and under the 25th percentile historically, and the low tNERDs for both clubs confirm the vibe: more background baseball than red‚Äëcarpet event. The on‚Äëfield draw is Bradish, who‚Äôs slated to face Sean Burke; in a tiny 2025 sample Bradish brings a tidy 5.25 K/BB and 0.94 WHIP, while Burke returns with live velocity and a walk rate that can wander. Baltimore‚Äôs coming off an emphatic sweep at Toronto, and Chicago just got broomed by Cleveland, which doesn‚Äôt boost the watchability math.

There are storylines, though. Bradish‚Äôs matchup history here is real, and he‚Äôs officially lined up again opposite Burke per MLB‚Äôs preview; if command shows up, strikeouts should follow. Baltimore did activate Tyler O‚ÄôNeill as a lineup jolt, but the broader offensive/defensive profiles (reflected in those modest tNERDs) remain light. If you prioritize pitching intrigue over crisp team play, you‚Äôve found your mid‚Äëcard.

Cincinnati Reds @ St. Louis Cardinals, 4:45p

Summary

Ball-in-play theater in Busch: Zack Littell‚Äôs contact-heavy, homer-prone profile runs into the Cardinals‚Äô glove-first identity, while both clubs still have a pulse in the NL wild-card chase. Expect more action than whiffs, and a result that swings on who handles all those balls in play.

The gNERD sits at 7.73, a tick below today‚Äôs slate average, and the components explain why: average-ish pNERDs (Littell 4.10, Liberatore 4.03) with low swing-and-miss rates but solid strike-throwing point toward pace and traffic over strikeouts; their xFIP-s (104/106) frame both as near-league-average run preventers. Cincinnati‚Äôs watchability leans on speed (positive baserunning) more than thump (poor barrel rate), while St. Louis brings run-saving defense and a steady bullpen.

As for storylines: the Reds just acquired Littell, who‚Äôs limited homers better on the road since joining Cincinnati but still leads MLB in long balls allowed, which keeps volatility high; Liberatore‚Äôs recent line includes a five-run stumble in Seattle after a midseason run of quality starts.

Injuries nudge things, too: Masyn Winn‚Äîcentral to that elite Cards defense‚Äîis shut down, while Nolan Arenado has been working back from a shoulder strain with a target of returning around this series; the Cards‚Äô late-inning mix has settled with Riley O‚ÄôBrien snagging saves.
